isis.stitle: VT 275 Engine Diagnostics Manual - Performance Diagnostics - Test Procedures - 12. Boost Control

svcprocinfo.para: PurposeTo verify Turbocharger Bypass Control (TCBC) is operating correctly.

entry.para: Hose and adapters from vacuum pump kit

warning.para: To avoid personal injury, death, including damage to the engine or vehicle, read all safety instructions in the "Safety Information" section of this manual.

figure.caption: Turbocharger pneumatic actuator linkage connection to bypass valve lever

step1.para: Inspect the turbocharger pneumatic actuator linkage connection to bypass valve.

item.para: If the actuator linkage is disconnected, continue with step 2.
If the actuator linkage is connected, do " Test 12.2. Actuator and Bypass Valve Operation ."

step1.para: Check the bypass valve lever for freedom of movement.

item.para: If the bypass valve lever moves freely, connect the pneumatic actuator linkage, do " Test 12.2. Actuator and Valve Operation ."

If the bypass valve lever is hard to move. Remove the bypass valve cover, inspect the internal components for damage. Clean bypass valve if possible or replace turbocharger, and retest. When replacing the bypass valve cover, replace the cover gasket and torque the fasteners to 13.6 N·m (120 lbf·in).

step1.para:
See " Appendix A: VT 275 Performance Specifications
" for specifications and record on Diagnostic Form.

figure.caption: Boost pressure tube connector on inlet elbow

step1.para: Disconnect the boost pressure tube from the intake manifold inlet elbow. Inspect all boost pressure tube connectors when removed for cracking.

figure.caption: Actuator and bypass valve operational test

step1.para: Attach pressure tubing from the Gauge Bar Tool hand pump and 0-30 psi gauge to the boost pressure tube.

note.para: Use adapters from a vacuum pump kit to make test hose connections.

step1.para: Mark a reference spot on the linkage shaft.

Using the Gauge Bar Tool hand pump, apply pressure to the pneumatic actuator. As pressure starts to build up, linkage movement (indicated by mark on the linkage) should begin to move at specified pressure.

note.para: If unable to build pressure with the hand pump, attach shop air to the regulator and 0-30 psi gauge on the Gauge Bar Tool to supply air pressure. Gradually increase air pressure (do not exceed 30 psi) to check linkage movement and test for leaks.

step1.para: Record results on the Diagnostic Form.

item.para: If the pneumatic actuator linkage moves, and test pressure is within specification, continue with " Test 12.3. BCS Control ."
If the pneumatic actuator linkage does not move, or initial movement is not at specified pressure, continue with Step 7.

step1.para: With pressure applied spray leak detector or soap solution on the boost pressure tubes including the pneumatic actuator housing and pneumatic actuator housing. Also leak test of boost pressure tube to the BCS, the BCS housing, and all rubber connectors.

item.para: If boost pressure tubes are leaking, replace and retest.
If the BCS housing is leaking, replace and retest.
If pneumatic actuator is leaking do " Test 12.4. Pneumatic Actuator Operation " in this section to verify pneumatic actuator leakage.
If the pneumatic actuator linkage does not move, or initial movement is not at specified pressure, and there are no leaks, do " Test 12.4. Pneumatic Actuator Operation " in this section.

step1.para: Connect the EZ-Tech® interface cable to the EST and the ATA connector.
Turn ignition switch to ON. (Do not crank engine.)
Select D_OutputStateTest.ssn from the Open Session File window, select Open to open the session.
Using the Gauge Bar Tool hand pump, apply pressure of 172 kPa (25 psi), do not exceed 206 kPa (30 psi) to the pneumatic actuator through the supply tube and fully open the bypass valve.

note.para: Shop air may be used to supply air pressure. Attach shop air to the regulator and 0-30 psi gauge on the Gauge Bar Tool to supply air pressure. Gradually increase air pressure, do not exceed 206 kPa (30 psi) to open bypass valve.

step1.para: Select Diagnostics from the menu bar.
Select Key-On Engine-Off Tests from the drop down menu.

note.para: When using the EST to do KOEO or KOER diagnostic tests, Standard test is always selected and run first. If the ignition switch is not cycled, the Standard test does not have to be run again.

step1.para: From the KOEO Diagnostics menu, select Output State Test High and select Run to start the test.

item.para:
If the bypass valve linkage moves to the closed position, the boost control system is working correctly, do " Test 13. Torque Converter Stall
."

If the bypass valve linkage does not move to the closed position, see " BCS (Boost Control Solenoid) Assembly
" in the " Electronic Control Systems Diagnostics
" section of this manual.

step1.para: When finished with this test, select Session from menu bar, then Close.

figure.caption: Pressure control connector on pneumatic actuator

step1.para: Disconnect pressure tube connector from the bottom of the pneumatic actuator.
Attach pressure tubing from the Gauge Bar Tool hand pump and 0-30 psi gauge to the bottom of the pneumatic actuator.

note.para: Use adapters from a vacuum pump kit to make test tube connections.

step1.para: Using the Gauge Bar Tool hand pump, apply pressure to the pneumatic actuator. As pressure starts to build up, linkage movement (indicated by mark on the linkage) should begin to move at specified pressure.

note.para: If unable to build pressure with the hand pump, attach shop air to the regulator and 0-30 psi gauge on the Gauge Bar Tool to supply air pressure. Gradually increase air pressure, do not exceed 206 kPa (30 psi) to check linkage movement and test for leaks.

step1.para: Record pressure reading on the Diagnostic Form.

item.para: If the pneumatic actuator linkage moves, test pressure is within specifications, and there is no leak, continue with Step 5.
If the pneumatic actuator linkage does not move, or initial movement is not at specified pressure, continue with Step 6.

step1.para:
Check BCS assembly electrical circuits, see " BCS (Boost Control Solenoid) Assembly
" in the " Electronic Control Systems Diagnostics
" section of this manual.

item.para: If electrical control is operating properly, check BCS assembly. It could be stuck in the vent position. If BCS assembly is stuck, replace and retest.
If electrical control circuits are not operating properly, repair as needed and retest.

step1.para: With pressure applied spray leak detector or soap solution around the boost pressure tube to the pneumatic actuator and pneumatic actuator housing.

item.para: If pneumatic actuator is leaking, replace and retest.
If pneumatic actuator is not leaking, continue with Step 7.

figure.caption: Turbocharger pneumatic actuator linkage connection to bypass valve

step1.para: Disconnect pneumatic actuator linkage at the bypass valve, check the bypass valve lever for freedom of movement.

item.para: If the bypass valve lever moves freely, replace the pneumatic actuator and retest.
If the bypass valve lever is hard to move or is stuck. Remove the bypass valve cover, inspect the internal components for damage, clean and free up the bypass valve and retest.
If unable to clean and free up the bypass valve, replace the turbocharger.
